narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is one of the classes which will shape how you see the past and the future. I am a potential economics major and this class taught me so much more than just history. Or think something akin to APUSH - the history most of us know in a traditional sense. One theme that Gaddis is trying to instill in the class is that history is so much more beyond historical facts about politics and war, and indeed we spent many discussions on topics ranging from seismology and epidemiology (what a fitting time to do so), to mathematics and economics. Besides, my writing and reading improved a lot throughout the course.
Critical thinking and creative thinking.

The value of history, and its lessons. Our discussions were fantastic and surveyed the ethics of historic analysis, historians' methods and repercussions. It also instills the ability to analyze, discuss, and write well. This course has opened
Critical thinking about the nature of the subject of history as opposed to just learning history.

The answer to this is both "I don't know" and "So much." I routinely apply the lessons we learned in this courseabout history, yes, but also about purpose, humanity, perspective, and the brilliance of metaphorsto the lenses through which I look at the world and the ideas I try to explain to others. Without my really noticing, honestly, the materials we read and the ideas we discussed have percolated into my worldview. It's hard to describe what, exactly, I've learned beyond those vague descriptors without spoiling the course, but I'll just say that this course has gifted me new modes of thought and new modes of expression.
I got excellent writing feedback, and worked a lot on practicing writing.

An exploration of the discipline of history from a range of perspectives. This class challenged/helped me deepen my thinking on the purpose of history and the various ways we approach the past. Thoroughly enjoyed the readings and the class discussions!
Critical thinking about historical sources, a comprehensive understanding of history in the abstract and the difficulties in defining what 'history' is, how to read and write about history.
I gained greater insight into the craft of history and how I personally want to further pursue its study.

This course was one of the most informative and interesting classes I've taken. The discussion was very deep and fruitful, and I gained insight into the meaning of history. I also learned a lot about my writing skills.
My critical thinking skills and historical reasoning skills improved.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: you are taking a class with John Gaddis and you get to know him quite intimately (wait for the last class...), and you get to reflect upon something new after every discussion. 
Weaknesses: the scope of the class might be too broad for some since we don't spend more than a week on a specific historical period, and the reading can be quite hefty.

Strengths: Professor Gaddis is fantastic. He lets students direct discussion but also offers his own insights and experiences (though I would have liked to hear a little more about his own experiences). The reading assignments were usually interesting though only vaguely related to each other. Writing assignments were fun and unusual. Weaknesses: None apart from the rather large amount of reading.

Strengths - the fascinating readings, legendary professors, writing tasks and learning experiences
Weaknesses - Nothing
Strengths: Professor Gaddis is a fountain of knowledge, and you can learn so much just by engaging with him in discussion. The reading list was extremely interesting.

Strengths: The course description self-selects for masochists, so you'll end up with a group of very smart, often very insightful students from all over the world whose experiences will inform discussions and turn even well-trodden paths into unfamiliar trails. The copious readings are by and large fascinatingI read mine happily, and think frequently about themespecially the professor's own work. Being able to say, casually, "Yeah, I'm reading War and Peace," is, of course, an obvious plus (at least, that's one way of looking at it). And Gaddis is a clearly brilliant, engaging professor who will talk more than the course descriptor suggestsbut it's entirely worth it to have the chance to hear what he has to say, especially when he shares personal anecdotes from his career.

Weaknesses: One feels that there's a certain je ne sais quoi missing from virtual seminar, but there's nothing to do about that. Also: Gaddis may miss raised hands on Zoom, so don't be afraid to raise your voice (politely) instead. I would add that sometimes students' analyses of readings can be a little iterative, but that's only an occasional thing.
A truly amazing, inspiring class! Very structured and well organized. The only thing to improve is that the reading workload can be spaced out better.

Strengths: the strength of this class is its professor and content. Professor Gaddis was very engaging to listen to and would help to foster discussion. He was incredibly helpful and interested in the progress of all students. The books that we read all had a valuable contribution to the class. The writing assignments were also thought-provoking and flexible so that students could be creative with them.
Weaknesses: the value of the classes often depended on student discussion. If students had interesting comments and a conversation could form, the class was more insightful. Occasionally the discussion could become overly theoretical and students would share their thoughts without interacting with what someone else had said. The Zoom format did not help this.
The discussions were very intellectual and engaging, and all the readings were diverse and stimulating. The only weakness was the online format, which nothing could have changed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I can see that the discussion would have been better in person since that will allow more chances for people to bounce idea off of each other. It will also make it easier for Professor Gaddis since he doesn't have to remember who he just called all the time.
The virtual discussions were seamless and effective.
The way discussion is conducted over zoom could be improved. The raising hand method made the discussion more jolted and more like a series of monologues than an interactive exchange of ideas.
The seminar was conducted over zoom and overall went pretty smoothly. Professor Gaddis was also very accessible for individual meetings.

I think that my engagement with the class was decreased with its virtual format. Seminars are difficult over Zoom because it is hard for a discussion to develop naturally when the class isn't in front of each other. However, there isn't much way around this in the pandemic. Perhaps a clearer understanding of the 'hand-raising' protocol would help, as students in the beginning would speak over each other.
Despite the online learning environment, I still felt engaged in discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Would definitely recommend this if history remotely interests you and you are ready to read for some 8 hours on average every week. Don't get intimidated by War and Peace since you will come to like it.

Yes! Even if you don't usually like history, this course be fun and will make you appreciate the subject. It's a lot of work due to the reading load but Gaddis is an amazing professor and clearly loves teaching. The course will make you think about history in new and unusual ways.
If you get in, TAKE IT.

I would highly recommend it. The opportunity to learn with one of the most distinguished historians of our time is a privilege you cannot pass up. The readings and assignments will really push to become a more critical and creative thinker.
Yes, so long as you want to read, want to listen, and are willing to endure the occasional tangent punctuated by flashes of lucid insight.
YES! Take it, you won't regret it! It will more and less transform your views of history.

Yes! This course was deeply fascinating. Even if you have only a passing interest in history, you will leave this class with a greater appreciation for the historical forces at work in day to day life. The readings were an interesting collection of classics, essays, fiction, and non-fiction. The reading of War and Peace occurs throughout the whole semester, so every part of the class could be related back to the novel. The class has challenged me to think critically about history and articulate these thoughts in a discussion setting. Overall, as a first-year an exceptional class with a great professor!
I would recommend this course to anyone, provided that they are ready and willing to do lots of reading.
I would recommend this course. The material is interesting, the class discussions are stimulating, and the writing assignments are enjoyable and not too hard.
